Context: This text is about the Business Administration – Project Management program (B156) offered by George Brown College's School of Management. The program requires students to complete two semesters of work experience to graduate, which can be co-op (paid) or internship (unpaid). The text also mentions that the Centre for Business diplomas, advanced diplomas, and degree programs have been accredited globally by the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP), making George Brown one of only two colleges in Ontario with this accreditation. Context: The George Brown College offers a program with the code B156, which requires completion of 37 courses: 31 mandatory courses, 3 Business Electives, and 3 General Education Electives. Students also need to complete 2 Work Experience Terms, which can be in the form of co-op, internship, simulation, consulting, or research projects. International students are not eligible for optional co-op arrangements. The college provides field education opportunities with real-world challenges and clients through the Centre for Business. Graduates may find potential positions as assistant project managers, junior project managers/coordinators, project managers, project coordinators, or business project managers. George Brown College is a Global Registered Education Provider with the Project Management Institute (PMI) and prepares students to apply for either the Certified Associate in Project Management (CAPM) or Project Management Professional (PMP) certification from PMI. Students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) and MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation) before progressing to other courses but these do not count toward the 36 courses required for graduation. Students are advised to speak to the Business Office staff for assistance if needed.

Context:
To graduate from the college, students must complete three General Education courses from at least two of the following categories: Social Sciences (GSSC), Arts and Humanities (GHUM), or Science and Technology (GSCI). Students are required to make up any failed or dropped courses before graduation.

Students can make up these classes during the day, and some are offered in the evening through Continuing Education. It is important for students to check with the business office staff to ensure that Continuing Education courses are equivalent to what is taught in the full-time program. Some courses may not be offered in every semester, and the college staff can assist students with any special timetable requirements they may have.

The following is a list of courses offered in each semester:

Semester 1:
- BUS 1038: Business Concepts I (NONE)
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts (NONE)
- COMP 1010: Business Computer Applications I (NONE)
- HRM 1008: Fundamentals of HR Management (NONE)
- MARK 1020: Principles of Marketing I (NONE)
- MATH 1008: Math for Business & Management I (NONE)

Semester 2:
- ACCT 1036: Principles of Accounting (NONE)
- BUS 1040: Project Management (NONE)
- COMM 1034: Professional Communications I (COMM 2000 required)
- COMP 1115: Business Computer Applications II (COMP 1010 required)
- MATH 1095: Math for Business & Management II
- MATH 1008: Math for Business & Management I
- PSY 1129: Organizational Behaviour (NONE)

Semester 3:
- ECON 1032: Macroeconomics (NONE)
- MGMT 4009: Operations Management
- MGMT 2044: Scope and Quality Management (BUS 1040 & COMP 1115 required)
- STAT 1012: Business Statistics (MATH 1095 required)
- CMMK 1087: Human Skills (NONE)
- BUS 1000: Work Experience Prep Course (* this course only applies to students taking the Work Experience Option (B156), COMM 1007 & 3.0 GPA required)
- Select One General Education Elective

Semester 4:
- ACCT 2031: Managerial Accounting (ACCT 1036 required)

Students must complete courses from at least two of the following categories: Social Sciences (GSSC), Arts and Humanities (GHUM), or Science and Technology (GSCI). They are also required to make up any failed or dropped courses before graduation. Students can make up these classes during the day, and some are offered in the evening through Continuing Education. It is important for students to check with the business office staff to ensure that Continuing Education courses are equivalent to what is taught in the full-time program. Some courses may not be offered in every semester. The college staff can assist students with any special timetable requirements they may have.

Program Learning Outcomes:
- The graduate demonstrates the ability to evaluate the impact of global issues on an organization’s business opportunities by using an environmental scan.
- The graduate applies principles of corporate sustainability, corporate social responsibility and ethics to support an organization’s operations.

Context:
* Brown College has admission requirements that include academic achievement and may have other selection criteria.
* Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent is required, including grade 12 English (C or U) and grade 11 math (C, M or U) or grade 12 (C or U).
* Mature students (19 years of age or older and no OSSD) may need to take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or upgrade credits.
* George Brown College offers course exemptions based on college and university credits.
* Applicants must have proficiency in English communications.
* International students should apply through the Online Application System and visit the International Admissions page for country-specific requirements.
* Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.
* Information sessions are held regularly for domestic students to learn about programs, meet professors and staff, and experience classroom environment.
* For inquiries about domestic admissions, contact the Admissions Office at [admissions@georgebrown.ca](mailto:admissions@georgebrown.ca) or visit the Admissions section.
* For international student inquiries, contact a recruitment representative through virtual meeting or submission of an inquiry on the International Contact Us page.
* For financial aid inquiries, contact the Financial Aid Office at FinAid.

Context:
For financial inquiries, contact the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid section.

For advice on program options and which program might be best suited, make an appointment to see an Entry Advisor. For questions regarding programs at the Centre for Business, contact business@georgebrown.ca or (416) 415-5000 ext. 2160. The Business Administration – Project Management (B126/156) program is offered out of the School of Management and classes usually take place at the St. James Campus, mainly at 200 King St. E., and 290 Adelaide St. E., Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Saifur Rahman is the Program Co-ordinator for this program and can be contacted at MdSaifur.Rahman@georgebrown.ca.

International students can contact one of George Brown's international recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry through the International Contact Us page. Campus tours are offered regularly and can be signed up for on the website. Programs related to Project Management (B415) and International Business Management (B411) are also available.

Email communications from George Brown College can be received by signing up with your first name, last name, email address, and indicating whether you are a domestic or international student and your country of origin. You must have JavaScript enabled to use the form.
